724759f-a.text:
Whitehall Street, north from South Street (right, not shown). This locale is known as South Ferry (the photographer's vantage point), and Battery Park and State St. are on the left. In the center is the old Produce Exchange between Water and Pearl Streets. This site was later improved with the formidable Army Building. Across the roof appears the spire of Trinity Church, while to the right is the top St. Paul's Chapel.
186O's
Gift of Urbrock Collection
724759f-a.folder: White Street & South Street, Manhattan, NY

Street.
September 4, 1934.

Note: The corner building is the old Eastern Hotel.

723226f-b.text:
South Street, north side, from Whitehall to Moore Street's (left to right), showing buildings at this extremity. The South Ferry "El" station at the Battery is at the left margin. Views 2 & 3 are limited to the structures at Moore Street. Overhead in the last item are several Goodyear Co. blimps according to the photographer.
May 20, 1939
No's. 1-2-3
P. L. Sperr

723224f-b.text:
South Street, east of Whitehall Street, as photographed from the South Ferry "El' station platform. On the right are the various East River piers. Note the early sailing vessels. On the left is the Eastern Hotel and known as such since 1856. The original building was erected prior to 1790, when it was purchased by John B. Coles for 350 pounds. In 1822 it became the Eagle Hotel, a tavern. Much of the frame work is solid mahogany, having been imported as ballast by the original owner, a sea captain. At the time of purchase by Coles, who used it as a warehouse, it was 3 stories in height.
1:       1893
2: Sept. 1927
J. S. Johnston, photo
Gift of the Seamen's Church Institute
George L. Balgue, photo
723224f-b.folder: South Street & Whitehall Street, Manhattan, NY

724760f-a.text:
(1)
Whitehall Street, at, adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of South Street. Also shown is South Street, at the N.E. corner of Whitehall
Street.
October 10, 1932.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
An earlier view of the corner building which was the former Eastern Hotel and known as such, since 1856. The original building was erected prior to 1790, when it was purchased by John B. Coles for 350 pounds. In 1822 it became the Eagle Hotel, a tavern. Much of the frame work is solid mahogany, having been imported as ballast by the original owner, a sea captain. At the time of purchase by Coles, who used it as a warehouse,
it was 3-stories high.
October 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
724760f-a.folder: White Street & South Street, Manhattan, NY
